Review Exploring catalyst developments in heterogeneous CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and ethanol: A journey through reaction pathways Rasoul Salami Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Investigation Data curation Conceptualization a Yimin Zeng Writing – review & editing b Xue Han Writing – review & editing b ⁎ Sohrab Rohani Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ Ying Zheng Writing – review & editing Supervision a ⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Western University, London N6A 5B9, ON, Canada Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering Western University London ON N6A 5B9 Canada Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Western University, London N6A 5B9, ON, Canada b CanmetMATERIALS, Natural Resources Canada, Hamilton L8P 0A5, ON, Canada CanmetMATERIALS Natural Resources Canada Hamilton ON L8P 0A5 Canada CanmetMATERIALS, Natural Resources Canada, Hamilton L8P 0A5, ON, Canada ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Examining catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and ethanol, this review explores catalytic mechanisms, catalyst structural properties, and recent advancements in catalyst development for improved efficiency and selectivity. The pursuit of alternative fuel generation technologies has gained momentum due to the diminishing reserves of fossil fuels and global warming from increased CO2 emission. Among the proposed methods, the hydrogenation of CO2 to produce marketable carbon-based products like methanol and ethanol is a practical approach that offers great potential to reduce CO2 emissions. Although significant volumes of methanol are currently produced from CO2, developing highly efficient and stable catalysts is crucial for further enhancing conversion and selectivity, thereby reducing process costs. An in-depth examination of the differences and similarities in the reaction pathways for methanol and ethanol production highlights the key factors that drive C–C coupling. Identifying these factors guides us toward developing more effective catalysts for ethanol synthesis. In this paper, we explore how different catalysts, through the production of various intermediates, can initiate the synthesis of methanol or ethanol. The catalytic mechanisms proposed by spectroscopic techniques and theoretical calculations, including operando X-ray methods, FTIR analysis, and DFT calculations, are summarized and presented. The following discussion explores the structural properties and composition of catalysts that influence C–C coupling and optimize the conversion rate of CO2 into ethanol. Lastly, the review examines recent catalysts employed for selective methanol and ethanol production, focusing on single-atom catalysts. Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol Ethanol Catalytic mechanism Operando techniques Single atom catalyst Tandem catalyst 1 Introduction Global communities are striving to find sustainable alternatives to fossil fuels, driven by concerns about fossil resource depletion, global warming, and other serious environmental consequences of fossil fuel combustion. Fossil fuel combustion is the primary source of anthropogenic greenhouse gases (GHG), including CO2, CH4, NOx, and SOx [1,2]. Transitioning to sustainable energy production such as the production of biomethane, methanol, ethanol, hydrocarbons, ammonia from wastes and CO2 supports the objectives of decreasing dependence on fossil fuels and reducing carbon emissions [3–7]. Over the past few decades, methanol and ethanol have emerged as promising alternatives among various candidates, due to their significant advantages such as rapid burning velocity and substantial oxygen content. Beyond their ability as excellent fuel additives, they are widely used as solvents and molecular platforms for the synthesis of crucial chemical components and products. These promising applications across various industries have significantly contributed to the burgeoning market demand for methanol and ethanol [1,8]. A conventional method in methanol production is steam methane reforming (SMR), where syngas (a mixture of H2 and CO) is generated via the interaction of methane (CH4) with water (H2O). The generated syngas is then converted into methanol through a catalytic reaction [1,9,10]. Different from that, ethanol is mainly produced through a biological fermentation process that utilizes microbial activity (typically involving yeast) to transform sugars from various feedstocks (such as corn and sugarcane) into ethanol. During the production, several key steps are involved, including pretreatment of fermentable sugar-containing solution, fermentation of sugars, and distillation for the separation and purification of ethanol [11]. Despite these conventional production routes, pioneer innovative and eco-friendly technology for the conversion of CO2 to methanol and ethanol has been proposed and developed in recent years. These efforts highlight a growing interest in sustainable solutions for utilizing CO2 as a feedstock in the production of valuable liquid fuels and chemicals. As mentioned above, CO2 is the byproduct of the combustion of petroleum products, natural gases, and coal. In recent years, there has been a surge in CO2 emissions to the environment, escalating by up to 5.4%. Considerable efforts have been employed to reduce CO2 through approaches like carbon capture and permanent storage. However, these methods alone cannot completely address the increasing CO2 emission issue [11,12]. Hence, There is a demand to convert CO2 into value-added chemicals like methane, ethanol, methanol, dimethyl ether, urea, and formic acid, among others [13,14]. The synthesis of methanol and ethanol from this environmentally harmful gas emerges as a particularly promising and practical concept [12,15–18]. There are primarily three pathways for methanol and ethanol production through CO2 hydrogenation, namely electro-catalysis [19,20], photo-catalysis [21], and thermo-catalysis [22,23]. Electro-catalysis involves the facilitation of multiple electron transfers within an aqueous solution in the presence of a catalyst. While electro-catalysis proves effective in advancing C–C bond coupling, it introduces the challenges of high consumption, low efficiency, and limited catalytic stability [24]. Photo-catalysis relies on utilizing light to generate electron-hole pairs on the surface of catalysts, initiating redox reactions. The effectiveness of photocatalysis is intricately tied to the semiconductor materials’ capacity to trap light, the efficiency in generating and separating photogenerated carriers, and the thermodynamic equilibrium governing surface catalytic reactions. This complexity hinders the industrialization of photocatalysis for methanol/ethanol synthesis [25]. In contrast, the thermo-catalysis processes show promise in industrial applications due to their higher energy density, improved mass transfer, and enhanced catalytic performance [26]. The pursuit of high-efficiency catalysts in the thermo-catalysis process is thus crucial due to the challenge posed by the necessity to activate highly stable CO2 molecules. Additionally, the exothermic nature of the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol and ethanol results in a lower equilibrium conversion rate at elevated temperatures, highlighting the importance of efficient catalysts. To design an effective catalyst, it is essential to uncover the reaction mechanism, identify key intermediates, and understand the kinetics to tailor the catalyst's structure and properties accordingly. With the expanding research focus on CO2 hydrogenation for methanol and ethanol production in recent years, numerous high-quality review papers have surfaced, delving into catalysts employed for each alcohol and scrutinizing the reaction pathway [17,22,25,27–30]. The conditions required to convert CO2 into methanol and ethanol through hydrogenation are similar, making the catalyst the critical element in determining the outcome. Consequently, it is critical to explore the composition of the catalyst, unraveling the specific catalyst surface features responsible for this distinction. Over the past years, insights into reaction pathways and intermediates involved in chemical reactions have been derived from in-situ analyses or density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Recent developments in this field have introduced operando X-ray methods, providing a more detailed level of information on the process. However, the significance and impact of these techniques in this area are still under study. Recent advancements in the field have witnessed a surge in more detailed information acquisition through operando X-ray methods. Particularly, in previous studies focusing on the hydrogenation of CO2, operando X-ray techniques have proven invaluable in elucidating active sites, their surrounding environment, and the oxidation states of metal catalysts. This innovative approach holds considerable promise for unraveling intricate catalytic reaction details, significantly influencing catalyst performance and design. Besides, well-established active metals such as Cu, Co, and Pd have been used for both methanol and ethanol production. The identification of intermediates and reaction pathways through diverse techniques offers valuable insights into adjusting the methanol-to-higher-alcohol ratio. While existing review papers extensively cover catalyst development and intermediates, categorizing results based on the techniques applied for uncovering reaction pathways provides a comprehensive resource for researchers seeking to employ specific methodologies in mechanistic studies. Furthermore, the comparison of results obtained from different techniques elucidates the concurrence or disparity of data, shedding light on the validity of each approach and guiding researchers toward more robust and reliable methodologies. In this review paper, diverse methodologies for identifying intermediates and investigating the reaction pathways involved in CO2 hydrogenation for methanol and ethanol production are explored. Subsequently, factors influencing ethanol production over methanol are scrutinized using available public and in-house databases. Moreover, recent advancements in catalyst development for both methanol and ethanol production are discussed, with an emphasis on novel strategies aimed at synthesizing more efficient catalysts. 2 Reaction pathways of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol or ethanol Fundamental thermodynamic parameters of chemical reactions, including the standard molar enthalpy change ( Δ H ° ) , standard Gibbs free energy change ( Δ G ° ) , and standard equilibrium constant ( K ° ) , provide crucial insights that can inform and direct the rational design of catalysts. Jia et al. conducted an in-depth thermodynamic analysis of the hydrogenation of CO2 to alcohols [31]. The key thermodynamic parameters relevant to this process are presented in Table 1 , which summarizes the critical reactions involved and their associated thermodynamic properties. Methane, a common by-product in alcohol synthesis, is thermodynamically favored because of its low Δ G ° (−113.5 kJ/mol) and high equilibrium constant ( K ° = 7.79 × 1019). The significant thermodynamic predominance of methane formation over alternative reactions, such as CO production or alcohol synthesis, underscores the irreversible nature of hydrocarbon formation under standard conditions. Therefore, one of the primary challenges in methanol or ethanol synthesis is to inhibit the excessive reduction of CO2 to methane. To address this, it is crucial to develop efficient catalysts that impose substantial activation energy to the formation of CH4, thereby steering the reaction pathways away from methane production and toward the desired products. He et al. [32] discovered that methane formation can be thermodynamically suppressed by decreasing the temperature, increasing the pressure, and raising the H2/CO2 ratio. Due to the endothermic nature of the reverse water–gas shift reaction that produces CO, lowering the temperature thermodynamically inhibits CO production (Table 1) while favoring the formation of alcohols at these reduced temperatures. Increasing pressure typically promotes the formation of alcohols over the isovolumetric reverse water–gas shift reaction. As a result, a major challenge in producing ethanol lies in balancing the energy-intensive activation of CO2 with the coupling of carbon–carbon bonds, while also minimizing side reactions like CO2 methanation, methanol synthesis, and the RWGS reaction. Thus, the primary difficulty in producing ethanol is to develop catalysts capable of simultaneously activating CO2, facilitating carbon chain growth, and preventing excessive hydrogenation into hydrocarbons [33]. Although the formation of C2+ alcohols is thermodynamically more favorable than ethanol, their production is less likely due to the high energy barrier associated with the creation of additional CC bonds. The adsorption of molecules on a surface is a critical initial step in heterogeneous catalytic processes, providing a foundation for subsequent chemical reactions. Carbon dioxide molecules can be adsorbed by carbon or oxygen atoms, driven by forces such as van der Waals forces or electrostatic interactions. The nature and strength of this adsorption depend on the catalyst materials. In the CO2 molecule, the Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital (HOMO) 1πg is close to oxygen, while the Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital (LUMO) 2πu is close to carbon. Oxygen functions as a weak Lewis base by donating electrons, whereas carbon serves as a weak Lewis acid by accepting electrons. In reactions involving a proton and hydride resulting in H2 dissociation, CO2* (* representing the adsorbed species) undergoes hydrogenation to form HCOO* and COOH* (Eqs. (1) and (2)), respectively). Moreover, carbon monoxide is recognized as another intermediate in CO2 activation, which can also be considered a product as it is stable in the reverse syngas reaction (Eq. (3)). Therefore, there are three primary intermediates for CO2 hydrogenation: COOH*, HCOO*, and CO. By regulating the hydrogenation and C–O cleavage of these intermediates on the catalyst surface, they can be converted into secondary intermediates such as CHxO and CHx (COOH* → CO* → CHO* → CH2O* → CH2* → CH3* or HCOO* → HCOOH* → H2COOH*→ H2CO* → CH2* → CH3*). As long as coupling does not occur, these secondary intermediates can ultimately lead to the production of C1 products, including carbon monoxide, methane, methanol, formaldehyde, or formic acid. (1) CO2* + H → HCOO* (2) CO2* + H → COOH* (3) CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O When CC coupling occurs, ethanol can be generated among diverse products, with the catalyst composition playing a decisive role in determining the product ratio. For ethanol production, CC coupling occurs between oxygenate intermediates (CO, HCOO, CHxO) and non-oxygenate intermediates (CHx) (Eqs. (4)–(6)). Following that, C2 intermediates, CHxCHxO, undergo additional hydrogenation, ultimately leading to the production of ethanol. (4) CO* + CHx* → CHxCO* (5) CHxO* + CHx* → CHxOCHx* (6) HCOO* + CHx* → CHxCHOO* Extensive efforts have been dedicated to identifying intermediates involved in the reaction of hydrogenation of CO2. These endeavors have taken the form of in-situ techniques, where reactions are studied under real-time conditions, providing valuable insights into the dynamic processes at play. Additionally, DFT calculations have been employed to explore the energy levels of intermediates, offering a theoretical framework to assign possible and impossible routes of the reaction. The combination of in-situ techniques and DFT calculations presents a comprehensive approach, merging experimental observations with computational insights, thereby enhancing our understanding of CO2 hydrogenation mechanisms and paving the way for advancements in sustainable and efficient methanol and ethanol synthesis processes. Moreover, kinetic studies can provide further details about the reaction mechanism. In the following sections, various methods employed to elucidate the reaction pathway of heterogeneous catalytic processes for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and ethanol using different catalysts have been studied. 2.1 Revealing reaction pathways through in-situ techniques In the realm of in-situ techniques, infrared (IR) spectroscopy is widely available and accessible to researchers, making it a common choice for in-situ investigation of chemical reactions. This is primarily because IR spectroscopy is widely available and accessible to researchers, making it a common choice for investigating chemical reactions in-situ. IR spectroscopy offers rapid data acquisition and analysis, allowing researchers to monitor reactions in real-time and observe changes in intermediate species. Moreover, IR spectroscopy is non-destructive and can be applied to various samples, making it versatile for studying various reaction conditions and catalyst systems. Its ability to provide valuable information about molecular structure and functional groups also contributes to its utility in studying intermediates during chemical reactions. However, IR technique falls short in providing information about the structural transformations of active sites and binding sites of intermediates, particularly when multiple active sites are involved. For instance, the in-situ IR mechanism study on the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst can not discern which intermediates are associated with Zn and which are bonded to Cu. Recognizing this limitation, recent years have witnessed the adoption of more advanced X-ray methods such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) for in-situ analysis, offering a more comprehensive approach to uncovering mechanistic details. XAS provides detailed information about the local coordination environment and oxidation state of elements, allowing for precise identification of active sites and intermediates. XRPD on the other hand, offers insights into the crystal structure and phase composition of catalysts under reaction conditions. These advanced techniques overcome the limitations of IR spectroscopy by offering a more comprehensive understanding of structural transformations and binding sites. However, it is noted that these advanced X-ray techniques also have their limitations. XAS requires synchrotron radiation facilities, which may not be readily accessible to all researchers. Additionally, XRPD may struggle to detect small changes in crystal structure or phase composition, particularly in complex catalyst systems. 2.1.1 Unraveling methanol mechanisms using operando X-ray techniques In delving into the mechanism of CO2 conversion to methanol, the intricate details of the reaction mechanism of commercial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst have long been a subject of debate. To address this, Zabilskiy et al. [34] utilized high-pressure operando methods, including steady-state isotope transient kinetic analysis, FTIR, time-resolved XAS, and X-ray diffraction (XRD), in combination with transmission electron microscopy (TEM), to reveal significant insights. The investigation established that zinc formate emerges as the predominant reactive intermediate when exposed to H2, undergoing conversion into CH3OH. Operando measurements were conducted to ascertain the specific site of formate species on the copper-zinc catalyst’s surface. To observe the catalyst’s responses induced by the reaction, it underwent pretreatment in pure H2, followed by exposure to reactants. Under reaction conditions, the copper-zinc alloy experienced oxidation, resulting in the formation of zinc formate, zinc oxide, and metallic copper. Notably, the close interaction between zinc and copper phases facilitates the formation of zinc formate and its subsequent hydrogenation into methanol. Through the examination of Zn K-edge XAS spectra, specifically X-ray Absorption Near Edge Structure (XANES), it was noted that under H2 conditions, Zn existed in two species (ZnO and Cu0.67Zn0.33). However, under reaction conditions, Zn was observed in three distinct species (ZnO, Cu0.67Zn0.33, and Zn-formate). The catalyst transformed into a Cu-Zn alloy under harsh reduction condition, yet proved unstable when exposed to CO2, leading to oxidation and the generation of ZnO and surface Zn-CHOO. The XANES for Cu under pure H2 and CO2/H2 mixture atmosphere revealed that the state of Cu remained unchanged, existing as Cu0 under both atmospheres. These integrated findings suggest that Zn-CHOO operates as the primary detectable reactive intermediate during the methanol production process on Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. Conducting Operando X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) data at gas–solid interfaces allows for a comprehensive understanding of the electronic properties of heterogeneous catalysts and the intermediate species involved during chemical reactions. This technique is employed under actual reaction conditions, coupled with mass spectrometry in a differentially pumped lens chamber, enabling the examination of catalytic reactivity and selectivity in real-time [35,36]. Using hard X-ray as the excitation source enables XPS measurements at higher pressures, providing a distinct advantage for operando photoelectron spectroscopy during catalytic conversion processes involving less reactive molecules like carbon dioxide [37,38]. Koitaya and collaborators utilized operando ambient-pressure hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (AP-HAXPES) for the first time to investigate the hydrogenation of CO2 on a copper-zinc-alumina catalyst employed in methanol synthesis [39]. AP-HAXPES revealed the real-time formation of metallic copper particles and the introduction of aluminum atoms into zinc oxide during the catalyst's reduction process under a hydrogen atmosphere. Mass spectrometry analysis of the reaction products under near-ambient pressure conditions of CO2 and H2 gases revealed the production of CH3OH and CO through the reverse water–gas shift (rWGS) reaction. The temperature dependence of rWGS reaction and methanol synthesis displayed notable differences. For rWGS, the production of reaction products steadily increased as the temperature rose from 147 to 260 °C. In contrast, methanol synthesis rates peaked at 207 °C and decreased at elevated temperatures. AP-HAXPES experiments indicated that the decline in reactivity for methanol synthesis at 260 °C may be associated with the decomposition of formate. The earlier temperature-controlled desorption studies revealed that formate undergoes thermal decomposition on the ZnO surface, producing CO2, CO, and H2 in the temperature span from 227 to 337 °C [40]. Conversely, on the Cu sites at the Cu/ZnO interface, formate’s thermal decomposition occurred at a lower temperature, specifically between 127 and 227 °C [41]. Note that the ongoing HAXPES experiments failed to offer definitive evidence regarding the oxidation states of zinc sites in the real operational window because they were executed under gas-phase pressures considerably lower than those encountered in genuine catalytic conditions. Several additional studies have been undertaken to clarify the role of copper-zinc alloy in the synthesis of methanol from CO2 [42–44]. Frei et al. [42] conducted kinetic studies on an efficient Cu/ZnO:Al catalyst across a range of temperatures. Elevated temperatures under reductive conditions resulted in increased CuZn-alloy formation, as determined through in-situ XRD, in-situ XAS, and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM). In the study, it was revealed that surpassing 250 °C led to substantial detrimental effects on both the catalytic performance and the corresponding active sites. The reduction in the reaction rate, coupled with an increase in CuZn-alloy formation, can be attributed to several synergistic effects concentrated at the Cu–ZnO interface, encompassing structural, electronic, and mechanistic aspects. Under specified reducing conditions (20% H2/Ar), CuZn-alloy formation was facilitated. As the catalyst reached a critical threshold of CuZn-alloy, irreversible modifications occurred, resulting in a transformation of the active site. This transformation involved the removal of the O atom at the perimeter of Cu–O–Zn, impacting the catalytic activity significantly. Lam et al. [43] reported the presence of CuZnx alloy nanoparticles with remaining Zn2+ sites under reduction conditions at 733 K and in the presence of H2, as indicated by XAS analysis. Additionally, in-situ XAS demonstrated the partial conversion of CuZnx alloy into Cu0 and Zn2+ during the reaction. Zabilskiy et al. [44] developed a synthesis approach for generating Cu/ZnO materials that eliminates the need for traversing an alloy phase. Even under extremely reducing conditions (1.5 MPa of H2, 533 K), no reduction of zinc oxide or the formation of a copper-zinc alloy was detected. This observation suggested that achieving high methanol yields and selectivity does not necessitate the presence of a copper-zinc alloy phase. This research team additionally conducted a mechanistic investigation into Pd/ZnO catalysts, focusing on realistic conditions for methanol synthesis [45]. They employed in-situ XAS, XRD, and time-resolved isotope labeling experiments, complemented by FTIR and mass spectrometry. The presence of a Pd–Zn alloy phase is commonly linked to improved activity and selectivity in methanol production during the hydrogenation of CO2 on Pd/ZnO catalysts [46–49]. In-depth mechanistic studies revealed that catalysts based on Pd-Zn alloy, formed by reducing a heterobimetallic Pd(II)-Zn(II) and lacking zinc oxide or any PdZn/ZnO interface, primarily yield CO. The formation of CO was specifically attributed to the Pd-Zn phase, which did not provide the active sites required for the direct CO2 hydrogenation into methanol. Thus, the coexistence of a phase of ZnO and a phase of Pd-Zn is crucial in facilitating the effective generation of methanol. To summarize, it can be concluded that in the well-known CuZnAl-based catalyst, The CuZn alloy likely plays a role in H–H bond dissociation due to its metallic nature, facilitating the activation of hydrogen. The Cu-ZnOx species may contribute to the stabilization and activation of CO2, while the Cu/ZnOx interface is essential for facilitating C–O bond dissociation, a key step in the formation of methanol. Thus, instead of a single active site, it is the cooperation between these different sites that drives the fundamental steps in methanol synthesis. Each component contributes uniquely to the overall catalytic process, making the CuZnAl-based catalyst highly effective for methanol production. Divin et al. conducted a comprehensive investigation using high-pressure operando spectroscopy techniques to analyze well-defined Cu and Cu0.7Zn0.3 nanoparticles supported on ZnO/Al2O3, γ-Al2O3, and SiO2 [50]. Their primary goal was to establish correlations among the structure, composition, and catalytic performance of these systems. Despite observing comparable activity and selectivity between Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 and CuZn/SiO2 in producing CH3OH, a temporal analysis revealed a decrease in methanol yield over the time of the reaction for the CuZn/SiO2 sample. Under operando conditions, the Zn K-edge XAS of CuZn/Al2O3 exhibited only minor changes, implying a lack of significant reduction in the incorporated Zn species within the Al2O3 matrix during calcination. In contrast, more substantial alterations were observed for CuZn/SiO2. This included a reduction in the intensity of the primary Zn K-edge XANES features and the emergence of a metallic Zn characteristic shoulder at the edge onset (Fig. 1 (b)). These changes were attributed to the Zn species in the sample undergoing partial reduction which was evident in the Zn K-edge EXAFS spectra. Notably, a new peak around 2.2 Å appeared in the Fourier transform (FT) spectra, systematically increasing during the reaction, indicative of the formation of Zn–Zn or Zn–Cu bonds. The intensity of this feature was initially low after a 2-hour reduction at 598 K but became more pronounced with prolonged reduction time. Investigating the influence of reducing environment at various temperatures on the oxidation state of Zn, the Zn K-edge XAS data for CuZn/SiO2 after 20 h of treatment in 10% H2 atmosphere at 518 K and 0.1 MPa showed similar changes. This extended study revealed an increasing metallic Zn contribution after 20 h compared to 1–2 h of reduction, indicating a slow and progressive reduction of Zn species. Additional experiments up to 873 K revealed the progressive rearrangement of the initial tetrahedral Zn configuration into a mixture of components with ZnO and metallic Zn species, as confirmed by EXAFS data fitting (Fig. 1(d)). Tsoukalou et al. [51] conducted an operando investigation on a model nanocrystalline In2O3 catalyst utilized in methanol synthesis through CO2 hydrogenation (at 300 °C and 20 bar). This examination involved the integration of XAS and XRD (Fig. 1(g)), unveiling three distinct catalytic stages in CO2 hydrogenation: activation, stable performance, and deactivation. In the activation phase, the crystalline structure of the bcc-In2O3 catalyst remains largely unaffected. The slight reduction in the In–O coordination number aligns with the creation of oxygen vacancy (Vo) sites, resulting in the formation of the active In2O3-x phase [52]. The study of the dynamic structural changes of In2O3 nanoparticles during the reaction time, using XANES-EXAFS-XRD techniques, intricately linked the activation step of the catalyst with a partial reduction of In2O3, donated as In2O3-x. As the catalytic reaction progressed, a transformative reduction-induced amorphization of In2O3 nanoparticles (NPs) unfolded. This transformation was characterized by a gradual reduction in both In–In and In–O coordination numbers, accompanied by a diminishing intensity of In2O3 Bragg peaks. The XANES data provided further confirmation of the formation of In2O3−x and the appearance of metallic In with the progression of Time on Stream (TOS). Of notable significance is the initiation of catalyst deactivation, which occurred precisely with the emergence of molten In0. This transformation was not only theoretically postulated but also visually substantiated through in-situ TEM conducted under reaction conditions at 0.8 bar. The in-situ TEM observations distinctly portrayed an electron beam-induced metamorphosis of In2O3 NPs, delineating a dynamic structure wherein amorphous and crystalline phases coexist harmoniously and perpetually undergo interconversion. These findings led to the conclusion that In2O3-x serves as the active phase, whereas the formation of In0 leads to catalyst deactivation. This research team also conducted a mechanistic study on In2O3 catalysts supported on monoclinic (m), tetragonal (t), and amorphous (am) ZrO2 [53]. They provided data regarding the changes in the oxidation state of In and structural alterations of the In2O3/ZrO2 catalysts during the reaction. Operando XAS-XRD results exhibited a homogeneous dispersion of In atoms for the In2O3/m-ZrO2 catalyst over time of stream. The active sites, known as In–Vo–Zr sites, were secured within a lattice exhibiting poor reducibility. This protection against deactivation due to over-reduction ultimately prevents the formation of liquid In. On the contrary, the amorphous ZrO2 support did not engage in the formation of a crystalline solid solution with In2O3. Consequently, In2O3/am-ZrO2 underwent reduction to In0 within the initial few minutes of exposure to the reaction condition. The zirconium oxide support effectively safeguarded dispersed indium oxide NPs (In2O3/t-ZrO2) from excessive reduction, albeit to a limited extent. Consequently, the resulting catalyst maintained a mean positive charge of In ions below +2. In other words, the catalyst experienced a partial loss of activity due to excess reduction. Their findings underscored that the tetragonal ZrO2 support dictates the formation of an active solid solution with indium, significantly influencing the reduction potential of In3+ ions and their coordination environment. They determined that the monoclinic solid solution m-ZrO2 is a superior catalyst for the straightforward hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol directly after comparing the stability and activity of various indium-based catalysts. This catalyst featured active In–Vo–Zr surface sites that exhibited greater stability against reduction compared to In–Vo–In species found in bixbyite-type In2O3. To investigate the characteristics of zinc in copper-zinc-zirconium catalysts, Yang et al. conducted a series of experiments [54]. They synthesized a range of Cu-Zn-Zr ternary catalysts with consistent components but varied Zn local structures. The controlled synthesis involved strengthening the interactions within Cu-Zn or Zn-Zn through the double-nozzle flame spray pyrolysis (DFSP) method. The catalysts demonstrated different methanol selectivity and yield in the following order: Cu-Zn-Zr > Zn-Cu-Zr > Zr-Cu-Zn. The operando XAS analysis revealed a dynamic structural evolution of zinc species. Under reaction conditions, atomically dispersed zinc sites emerged, attributed to the robust interaction between highly dispersed ZnO clusters and the ZrO2 support in the initial state of the Cu-Zn-Zr catalyst. For the Cu-Zn-Zr catalyst, the reduction of ZnO initiated around 240 °C, with less than 20% reduction at 300 °C. The ZnO chemical state remained nearly stable thereafter, indicating the formation of a stable structure. In contrast, both Zn-Cu-Zr and Zr-Cu-Zn samples exhibited easier reduction of ZnO at a relatively low temperature of 150 °C. In Zr-Cu-Zn, Zn species were gradually oxidized in a CO2 atmosphere and remained stable even upon hydrogen introduction. However, for Zn-Cu-Zr, oxidation occurred rapidly in CO2 and further intensified in the reaction atmosphere, underscoring the susceptibility of the Zn valence state to the gas environment. For a specific metal/titanium pair, it was demonstrated that the preference for methanol over methane or CO is highly contingent on the titanium phase and the character of the metal/oxide interaction [55,56]. Furthermore, the collaboration of late-transition metals with titanium oxides has become a fascinating area of study for the activation of carbon dioxide [57–59]. Let et al. discovered that when molybdenum was supported at an intermediate loading of 3 wt% on rutile titanium nanorods, it exhibited unexpected efficiency in methanol yield and methanol selectivity [59]. This study implied that the rutile nanorod (RNR) support has the potential to sustain single Mo ions with a lower positive charge compared to other titania supports. It is important to note, however, that these conclusions were derived from analyses conducted at low pressure, while the actual reaction took place at high pressures (20–30 bar), and Mo exhibited a high sensitivity to its chemical environment. Therefore, the research group employed operando XAS to examine the impact of support variation on the formation and characteristics of MoOx species during catalyst preparation [60]. The most effective supports for CO2 conversion are those with RNRs, with the catalyst containing molybdenum on RNRs demonstrating the highest activity and selectivity for methanol (Fig. 2 ). The preparation of Mo/TiO2 (RNR, DT51 Anatase, and P25) catalysts, along with their structural changes during reduction pretreatment and catalytic testing, was examined using operando XANES and EXAFS. It was observed that there was a transition in the average Mo oxidation state from VI to V between 200–300 °C, followed by another transition from V to IV between 300–500 °C. Continued heating resulted in the complete reduction of molybdenum. In the case of Mo/RNR, the structural changes induced by reaction conditions (3 H2 + CO2, 2 MPa) compared to reduction conditions (H2, 1 atm) are minimal, and the catalytically active species were identified as partially reduced Mo species. According to EXAFS analysis, Mo on anatase coordinates to significantly fewer atoms (4 first-neighbor O for 3Mo/DT51D) compared to rutile (5 first-neighbor O, 1 first-neighbor Mo, and 5 s-neighbor O for 3Mo/RNR) under the same reduction or reaction conditions. In addition to the stronger influence of Mo coverage and the gaseous atmosphere on anatase, they proposed that Mo species on anatase consist of surface-adsorbed Mo clusters and single atoms. In contrast, a substantial fraction of surface Ti atoms was substituted with Mo atoms in rutile, a configuration supported by in-situ XRD. This latter arrangement appeared to maximize the activity of CO2 hydrogenation and the selectivity toward methanol. 2.1.2 Unraveling mechanisms using in-situ IR spectroscopy 2.1.2.1 Methanol production pathway Infrared spectroscopy can be performed in different modes such as transmission, reflection absorption, diffuse reflection, and attenuated total reflection, as illustrated in Fig. 3 [61,62]. Among these modes, transmission and diffuse reflection are frequently employed for in-situ characterization of gas–solid catalytic reactions due to the easy design of the in-situ cells, which facilitate spectrum acquisition under reaction conditions. Fig. 3(a) depicts a standard in-situ cell used for the transmission mode. In this setup, catalyst powder is positioned in the path of an infrared laser while gas is introduced into the cell, which includes a heating element. To ensure proper sealing and infrared light transmission, two window sheets with low infrared absorbance are used; materials such as NaCl, BaF2, ZnSe, ZnS, CaF2, and KBr are suitable for the IR windows. Basu et al. developed an in-situ transmission infrared cell in a batch mode [63]. In this batch cell, the sample is pressed onto a heated tungsten grid with an attached thermocouple, enabling temperature control between 100 and 1000 K while maintaining ultra-high vacuum conditions. Additionally, Hicks et al. designed an in-situ flow cell for the transmission mode, which allows the reactant gas to flow through the catalyst bed [62]. The primary intermediate in the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol continues to be a subject of ongoing debate. Some proposed reaction pathways involve formate [64–71], while others dismiss formate as intermediates. An earlier study underscored the crucial role of carboxyl in the transformation of CO2 to methanol, proposing a sequence involving carboxyl isomerization, the formation of formate species, and subsequent hydrogenation to CH3OH [72]. An alternative viewpoint suggested that the crucial step consists of the formation of CO through the reverse water–gas shift, followed by the subsequent formation of formaldehyde [73] or hydroxycarbonyls [74]. Extensive research has delved into copper-based catalysts for CH3OH synthesis through CO2 reduction. Among various copper-based catalysts, Cu/ZrO2 systems stand out for their favorable performance, with previous studies focusing on elucidating the mechanisms underlying their effectiveness. Larmier et al. employed a comprehensive strategy involving both experimental techniques and computational methods on practical models to explore the mechanism of converting CO2 to methanol on a Cu/ZrO2 catalyst. Through a combination of kinetic analysis and spectroscopic examinations, their findings revealed that methanol primarily forms through the hydrogenation of formate, serving as a crucial reaction intermediate. Diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectroscopy (DRIFTS) showcased sole OH stretching frequencies observed at 3774 and 3670 cm−1 for the pristine catalyst at 230 °C. Upon exposure to an H2/CO2 mixture (3:1) at 230 °C and 1 bar, distinctive bands emerged in the stretch frequency regions of CH and CO species (Fig. 4 ). The primary broad OCO bands, peaking at 1593 cm−1 can be associated with carbonate (CO3*) or bicarbonate (CO3H*), while the bands at 2978, 2878, 2736, 1567, and 1387 cm−1 signify formate species adsorbed on zirconia (HCOO@ZrO2). The observed band at 1357 cm−1 could also be attributed to formate on copper. Emerging peaks at 2942 and 2828 cm−1, along with characteristic C–O stretching frequencies at 1154 and 1049 cm−1, were assigned to methoxy adsorbed on zirconia (Fig. 4) [74]. Surprisingly, employing solely zirconia revealed the existence of carbonate, bicarbonate, and formate species, implying that the introduction of copper onto zirconia is accountable for the generation of methoxy species. Solid-state NMR spectroscopy was utilized to identify species absorbed on zirconia. This technique cannot effectively indicate species on copper due to potential signal broadening on metallic copper. The 1H–13C NMR spectrum confirmed the presence of formate species at 1 bar and revealed an additional correlation indicative of surface methoxy species at 5 bar. These NMR results were consistent with in-situ DRIFTS findings, while the absence of carbonates in both ex-situ NMR and IR experiments suggested their weak adsorption. Additionally, formate and methoxy intermediates were identified for the reverse ZrO2/Cu catalyst through DRIFTS [71]. Major surface species, including formate and methoxy, were recognized, with formate exhibiting greater reactivity on the inverse catalyst compared to the traditional Cu/ZrO2 catalyst. Following exposure to the reaction atmosphere, an analysis of intensity changes in the IR signals revealed that the transformation of surface CO3*/HCO* species into CH3O* occurs more rapidly over the reverse ZrO2/Cu catalyst than over the conventional Cu/ZrO2 catalyst. Furthermore, it was shown that the CH3O* transform to CH3OH proceeds at a slower rate than the transformation of CO3*/HCO* species to CH3O* in the case of conventional catalysts. Conversely, on the reverse catalyst, the transformation of CH3O* to CH3OH was also a rapid step. Notably, in addition to the typically observed IR peaks, a distinctive band at 1350 cm−1 (HCOO-Cu) was evident over the reverse catalyst, a feature scarcely present on the traditional catalyst [75]. The newly appeared peak was identified as corresponding to the vibrational mode of the O–C–O within formate species, which are likely bonded either to copper atoms or at the metal interface [69]. According to these results, the metallic copper sites facilitate the hydrogenation of CH3O* and accelerate the conversion of oxygenates. Finally, it can be inferred that the superior performance of the reverse configuration with an optimized Zr/Cu ratio can be attributed to the accelerated hydrogenation of oxygenate intermediates compared to the conventional catalyst under comparable reaction parameters. A recent investigation unveiled three distinct formate types present on the surface of a Cu/ZrO2 catalyst during the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [76]. Among these, the Cu-bound formate, constituting approximately 7% of surface formates, displayed heightened reactivity and exclusively contributed to methanol production. The remaining two formates, situated on the ZrO2 surface, demonstrated considerably lower decomposition rates, with one exhibiting minimal reactivity. It is suggested that the formate situated nearer to the Cu-ZrO2 interface decomposes at a rate 65 times higher than the formate located farther away [77]. This research underscores the pivotal importance of the copper surface in influencing the rate-determining step of the process. The changes in key intermediate species during CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over Cu-Mn-Zn/ZrO2 catalysts with varying component ratios were studied using in-situ DRIFTS analysis [78]. Absorption peaks corresponding to carbonate (1492 and 1520 cm−1), formate (1380 cm−1), carboxyl (1585 cm−1), and methoxy (1048, 1457 cm−1) species were observed. These intermediates appeared at different times after CO2 introduction, with carboxyl and methoxy species appearing earlier on Cu3MnZn0.5Zr0.5 and Cu1MnZn0.5Zr0.5 than on Cu1MnZr0.5. The spectra remained unchanged after 15 min, indicating that carbonate, carboxyl, formate, and methoxy are key intermediates in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. The findings of the in-situ DRIFTS can be summarized as follows: CO2 adsorbs onto the metal oxide sites, forming CO3* species. These species react with H*, which may originate from hydrogen spillover from Cu sites, surface-adsorbed H2O, or surface-bound H*. This reaction generates key intermediates, including COOH*, HCOO*, and CH3O*. The CH3O* species is further hydrogenated to produce CH3OH*, which then desorbs as methanol. Concurrently, COOH* species can be hydrogenated to form CO*, which desorbs as CO. Additionally, some CO* species may undergo further hydrogenation to produce CH3O * and CH3OH *, thus contributing to methanol production upon desorption. FTIR investigations revealed that the conversion of CO2 on Pd-based catalysts follows two primary reaction pathways: (1) the generation of CO through the rWGS reaction, followed by hydrogenation, and (2) the generation of surface formate intermediates, subsequently undergoing hydrogenation [80,81]. Investigation of Ga2O3-Pd/SiO2 catalyst demonstrated that under standard operating conditions, this catalyst exhibits bifunctionality. Pd crystallites facilitate the generation of atomic hydrogens (Hs), whereas Ga2O3 patches adhering to the silica support play a crucial role in CO2 activation (through formates), thereby completing the reaction cycle [82,83]. The results of FTIR experiments yielded the following information [84]: (I) CO2 experiences a gradual conversion to monodentate formate, methylenebisoxy, methoxy, and methanol during hydrogenation; (II) all of these species are attached to gallium; (III) while the Ga2O3/SiO2 catalyst exhibits a limited ability to dissociate H2 [85], leading to modest methanol production during CO2 hydrogenation, the inclusion of Pd active sites significantly enhances methanol production. These combined observations support the concept of a bifunctional mechanism for methanol synthesis on Ga2O3–Pd/SiO2 catalysts, in which CO2 chemisorbs onto Ga2O3 and gradually converts to methanol through facilitated hydrogenation via atomic hydrogen spillover from Pd crystallites. In-situ investigations into the hydrogenation of CO2 and CO have been conducted utilizing a variety of catalysts. For instance, the use of a Pd/Ga2O3 catalyst revealed a higher rate of methanol synthesis during CO2 hydrogenation compared to CO hydrogenation. Interestingly, both reactions involved the formation of formates and methoxy species [86]. Conversely, when employing a Pd/ZrO2 catalyst, CO hydrogenation proceeded via formaldehyde and methoxy pathways, while CO2 hydrogenation followed the formate and methoxy pathways [85]. In summary, the DRIFTS investigation of Pd-based catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol provides confirmation that the process involves a formate intermediate pathway, succeeded by hydrogenation leading to the formation of methoxy and methanol. The presence of surface formate emerges as the critical factor in methanol formation, and this holds true regardless of the supports or promoters employed. In the context of Re/TiO2, the in-situ infrared analysis revealed the potential involvement of formate and methoxy as intermediates in the formation of CH3OH, whereas carbonyls emerged as possible intermediates contributing to the formation of CH4 [87,88]. In a recent examination, the catalytic performance of Re/TiO2 was explored under conditions of low temperature and high pressure, specifically at 150 °C and 331 bar [79]. Findings from diverse in-situ/operando spectroscopy methods, including DRIFTS, offered valuable insights into surface species, the oxidation state of Re, and structural changes in TiO2. Initially, time-resolved DRIFTS experiments were conducted over bare TiO2 to elucidate the influence of the TiO2 support. In the lack of Re metal, only monodentate carbonate (κ1-CO3), monodentate and bidentate bicarbonate (κ1-HCO3, κ2-HCO3), bicarbonate, and weakly adsorbed carbon dioxide (CO2) were observed on TiO2. Notably, there was no signal corresponding to C–H bonds in the 2500–3200 cm−1 region, confirming that formate cannot be generated in the absence of Re. CO3* and HCO3* are formed through interactions with CO2, utilizing lattice oxygen and the surface hydroxyl group (Ti–OH), respectively. Equivalent experiments on Re/TiO2 unveiled a temporal evolution of surface species in the following sequence: bidentate formate (κ2-HCOO*, 2950, 2869, 1560, and 1357 cm−1) and rhenium hydride (Re–H, 1965 cm−1) → linearcarbonyl (μ1-CO*, 2030 cm−1) and bridgecarbonyls (μ2-CO*, 1936 and 1880 cm−1) → bridgingformate (μ2-HCOO*, 2883, 2848, 2732, 1640, and 1405 cm−1) → methoxy (CH3O*, 2829 and 2927 cm−1). 2.1.2.2 Ethanol production pathway The catalytic pathway for ethanol synthesis involves CO2 activation, controlled hydrogenation, C–C bond formation, and hydroxylation, which are typically regulated by a heterogeneous catalyst. The initial step is common to various products, but it branches into different reactions leading to distinct end products in the second step. In the context of the second step, controlled hydrogenation, the focus of research has been on two pivotal intermediates. The predominant and widely accepted view posits that the synthesis of ethanol occurs through a carbonyl intermediate. This mechanism was initially introduced in 1996, employing a Rh-Fe/SiO2 catalyst [89,90]. In their study, the authors investigated the formation of ethanol through CO hydrogenation on SiO2-supported Rh and Fe active sites. To gain insight into the underlying reaction mechanism, they conducted in-situ infrared spectroscopy (IR) to monitor adsorbed species on the catalysts. The results revealed the presence of CO species adsorbed on the Rh surface for both 5 wt% Rh/SiO2 and 5 wt% Rh-Li/SiO2 (Rh: Li = 1) catalysts. They proposed a plausible mechanism for ethanol formation. Notably, two types of adsorbed CO species were identified in the FT-IR spectra on the Rh/SiO2 catalyst, characterized by bands at 2040 and 1860 cm−1, corresponding to linear and bridged CO species adsorbed on Rh, respectively. In contrast, the Rh-Li/SiO2 catalyst exhibited a more intensive bridged CO band. This difference in relative intensity was attributed to the varying selectivity of the catalysts. The bridged CO species interacted more strongly with the surface Rh, effectively occupying Rh sites and potentially suppressing hydrogen adsorption. As a result, hydrogenation to CH4 may be hindered over Rh-Li/SiO2 catalysts, making it easier for CO species to be inserted into a CH2–Rh bond, in comparison to Rh/SiO2 catalysts. Following the generation of the CO intermediate, a methoxy intermediate is generated. Ye et al. [91], in their investigation of Ir–In2O3 single-atom catalysts, observed the emergence of a significant CO intermediate (2076 cm−1) on Ir–In2O3 after exposure to CO2 at 200 °C, thereby confirming the formation of Irδ+–CO* as a pivotal intermediate in this catalytic process. Furthermore, during the hydrogenation process, the formation of another crucial intermediate, CH3O* (2856, 2960, and 2994 cm−1), was detected using in-situ FTIR. These peaks were rarely observed when using pure In2O3 based methanol catalysts, suggesting that the presence of Ir single atoms also contributes to the stabilization of methoxide on the oxygen vacancies of Ir–In2O3. To provide additional support for these findings, the 13CH3OH isotope experiment was conducted, leading to the conclusion that the stable intermediates of Irδ+–CO* and CH3O*–O vacancy played a pivotal role in CC coupling. Similarly, Han's work [92] on Pt/Co3O4 employed isotope labeling to trace the origin of carbon atoms in methanol during the catalytic synthesis of ethanol. The outcome revealed that carbon from methanol contributed to the formation of ethanol, as labeled carbon from methanol was detected in the final product. Concurrently, Zhang’s research introduced a multi-component catalyst of zeolite coated by carbon layer, H-MOR-DA@C, featuring Pt-Sn/CNT, for the catalytic synthesis of ethanol [93]. This approach involved the utilization of CH3OH for carbonylation, resulting in the production of CH3COOH, which was subsequently reduced to CH3CH2OH. Ding and colleagues [94], in their exploration of a Cu@Na-Beta catalyst, postulated a pathway driven by acetate/methoxy intermediates. Their proposed mechanism suggests that CO2 undergoes hydrogenation to form *CH3O and/or *CH3OH on the catalyst’s surface. This can occur via the rWGS reaction, followed by the reduction of generated *CO, or the reduction of adsorbed *CO2 to form *HCOO. The latter subsequently undergoes further reduction and CO cleavage, resulting in the formation of *CH3O or *CH3OH. Thereafter, *CH3O can break down into *CH3 and *O, and/or *CH3OH can decompose into *CH3 and *OH, yielding *CH3 species. The interaction of *CO2 with *CH3 or *CH3O in a CC coupling reaction leads to the formation of acetate species (*CH3COO). These *CH3COO species undergo additional hydrogenation, ultimately resulting in the production of ethanol, as described in Eqs. (7) and (8). (7) *CO2 + *CH3 + 2 H2 → *CH3CH2OH + *OH (8) *CO2 + *CH3O + 2 H2 → *CH3CH2OH + *O + *OH Some other researchers investigating the CO2 hydrogenation process for ethanol production found that CO2, when adsorbed on the catalyst’s surface, does not immediately dissociate at the active center. Instead, it facilitates the creation of HCOO* species alongside active H* species. These HCOO* species are further decomposed and readily coupled with CH3 species, resulting in the formation of CH3CO*. Subsequently, this compound is hydrogenated to yield ethanol. Xu et al. [95] conducted a study investigating the impact of promoters in the synthesis of higher alcohols (HAs) from the hydrogenation of CO2 under specific conditions (T = 330 °C, P = 5 MPa, and = 4500 h−1). They achieved a CO2 conversion rate of 36.6% and an ethanol yield of 1.12 mmol gcat −1 h−1 utilizing a Cs-CuFeZn catalyst. Their findings revealed two distinct reaction pathways: one occurring via the formate pathway and the other proceeding through the CO insertion pathway. The presence of Cu/ZnO within the catalyst aids in the production of methanol via the formate pathway. Conversely, in the CO insertion pathway, the Cs promoter plays a role in limiting methanol formation. The study observed that higher temperatures favor the rWGS reaction, thereby generating CO through the interaction of Cu/ZnO. Wang et al. [96] conducted an extensive study investigating the conversion of CO2 into ethanol using cobalt catalysts with incorporated nickel. Employing in-situ FT-IR analysis, distinctive CO2 adsorption bands were noted across various catalysts. Notably, the introduction of nickel significantly altered CO2 adsorption, leading to the emergence of formate species indicating that the adsorbed CO2 is partially hydrogenated [74,75]. Experiments involving catalysts with varying nickel content revealed the impact of nickel on the reaction intermediates, which notably enhances the production of *CHx species, pivotal in the CO2 hydrogenation process. Experimental identification [97–99] of *CHx species is challenging despite multiple proposed reaction pathways from computational simulations [100–102]. The potential mechanism involves a formate intermediate mechanism, involving a transformation of a formate portion into *CHx on the CoNi sites. Furthermore, 1H NMR spectroscopy unveiled unique resonances of *CH3 and *CH2 bonded to oxygen on the Co0.52Ni0.48AlOx catalyst. These findings were supported by the COSY spectrum, highlighting the presence of *CHx intermediates and their association with C1-oxygen species, potentially originating from a CC bond formation on the catalyst surface. Similarly, Liu et al. [103] proposed a formate/methoxy pathway in their study utilizing a Co/La2O3-La4Ga2O9 catalyst. They suggested that *CH3 and *HCOO species are generated from the reaction of dissociated and intact *CO2 with H atoms, respectively. The *HCOO species can decompose into *CO, which further couples with *CH3 to produce *CH3CO intermediates. Ethanol synthesis was then proposed to occur through the hydrogenation of *CH3CO. The *CHx intermediates generated in the hydrogenation of CO2 can engage in various alternate reactions beyond *CHx-*CO, resulting in a range of by-products including alkanes, alkenes, and additional alcohols [104]. The enhancement of catalytic performance is frequently achieved by applying surface functionalization with hydroxyl groups [105–109]. The modulation of the local concentration of hydrophilic reactants, like alcohols, around active sites is frequently attributed to the presence of surface hydroxyls. In a process of CO2 hydrogenation, hydroxyl groups present on hydrophilic SiC quantum dots exhibited the ability to boost methanol formation via an H-transfer mechanism. This mechanism entails the diffusion of hydrogen from hydroxyl groups to CO2, thereby aiding in the creation of the intermediate HCOO* [107]. Yang et al. highlighted the significance of hydroxyl groups on the RhFeLi/TiO2 catalyst, achieving a reactivity of 15% conversion and 32% ethanol selectivity in CO2 hydrogenation [110]. They demonstrated that surface hydroxyl species on RhFeLi/TiO2 nanorods can act as protonating agents for methanol, lowering the energy barrier for C–O bond scission. This process facilitates the creation of CH3 species. Consequently, carbon monoxide generated from the rWGS reaction can be incorporated into abundant CH3 species, leading to the formation of CH3CO, followed by hydrogenation of CH3CO to produce ethanol. 2.1.3 Unraveling mechanisms using other techniques In-situ TEM allows for the real-time observation of materials at the atomic level under varied environmental conditions, providing valuable insights into dynamic processes such as catalyst behavior during reactions. The objective of using this technique is to understand the structural and chemical changes occurring in catalysts during preparation and testing, which helps in optimizing their performance. Fiordaliso et al. [111] studied the development of the GaPd2/SiO2 catalyst by in-situ environmental TEM (ETEM) under a total pressure of 0.004 bar. The main purpose was to compare the results of the ETEM with those of the ex-situ identical location TEM (IL-TEM) study to assess the pressure dependency on the active phase formation. In both scenarios, the sizes and distributions of the nanoparticles were established during calcination, and no significant alterations in these characteristics were observed in the following reduction and catalytic reaction. Despite the different pressure conditions (0.004 bar for ETEM and 1 bar for IL-TEM), selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns identified the same crystal phases: PdO during calcination and GaPd2 upon reduction, for both cases. Despite ETEM indicating 15% metallic Pd presence, high-resolution images and electron diffractograms did not reveal pure Pd nanoparticles, likely due to sensitivity and resolution limitations compared to XRD. Yue et al. [112] conducted in-situ TEM to monitor the dynamic changes of active sites in nanoparticles. As shown in Fig. 5 , four nanoparticles positioned next to each other were observed, merging into two particles during the initial stage of CO2 hydrogenation. Since the reaction temperature was 260 °C, well below the melting point of Au (above 650 °C), the disappearance of the nanoparticles could not be attributed to melting. Instead, coalescence occurred due to variations in surface energy resulting from the different sizes of the Au nanoparticles. As a result, the larger nanoparticle grew while the smaller ones disappeared, a process known as the Ostwald ripening mechanism [113]. For particles of equal size, a coalescence phenomenon distinct from the Ostwald ripening mechanism was observed. As shown in Fig. 5(d), particle 5 and particle 3, which were nearly identical in size, were positioned close to each other. Subsequently, a contact neck with a precise alignment of atoms formed between particles 3 and 5, as depicted in Fig. 5(e), leading to their coalescence into particle 6 (Fig. 5(f)). Consequently, in the first few minutes of CO2 hydrogenation under heating conditions, the coalescence of Au nanoparticles was a complex and rapid process that integrated multiple coalescence mechanisms. As the CO2 hydrogenation reaction progressed, the smaller Au nanoparticles gradually vanished. Once the nanoparticles reached a final size of 5–10 nm, the rate of coalescence markedly lowered. With the size of the Au nanoparticles stabilizing, their selectivity for methanol remained relatively consistent. During this stage of the reaction, via in-situ observations of the Au nanoparticles, noticeable surface reconstruction and shape oscillation changes in the nanoparticles were revealed. Loza et al. [114] investigated the chemistry of methanol synthesis using in-situ 13C solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) for a commercialized Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. The research sought to explore several key questions regarding methanol synthesis. First, it aimed to determine whether methanol is synthesized from CO or CO2. Second, it examined the state of copper within the active catalyst. Third, it investigated the specific roles of ZnO and Al2O3 in the catalytic process. Finally, it sought to elucidate the overall reaction mechanism. To address these questions, the researchers studied the reactions of methanol, formic acid, paraformaldehyde, CO2, and CO on a Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst. Additionally, they analyzed the individual catalyst components (ZnO and Al2O3) and their combinations (Cu/Al2O3 and ZnO/Al2O3) to understand the contribution of each. The in-situ NMR results provided significant insights. Firstly, they found that both CO2 and CO interacted with the catalyst surface at low pressures, with CO2 being more readily adsorbed, forming carbonate species on Cu/ZnO/Al2O3. Secondly, T1 13C relaxation time measurements indicated that paramagnetic Cu(0) atoms or clusters were dispersed within the oxide phases of Cu/ZnO/ Al2O3. This suggested that, while the metal surface is crucial, dispersed clusters and the interaction between metal and oxide phases might also play important roles. Thirdly, the study revealed that ZnO, Al2O3, and ZnO/ Al2O3 were significantly reactive. Al2O3 formed a terminal methoxy group, whereas ZnO formed a bridging methoxy group. Formaldehyde disproportionated to formate and methoxy on these catalysts. Copper was essential for converting formate to carbonate and methoxy to formaldehyde and/or formate at 250 °C. While methanol synthesis at 250 °C required a metal component, the oxide phases were more reactive than merely supportive. Copper alone might catalyze all steps in methanol synthesis, but under the conditions studied, several adsorbed species were present on ZnO and Al2O3. Finally, the study provided important insights into the reaction mechanism. Although formaldehyde was too reactive to be detected as a free species, paraformaldehyde decomposition studies suggested it acted as an intermediary, potentially as a surface-bound dioxymethylene species. Formate, a common intermediate in many catalytic reactions, was easily generated and thoroughly characterized. On Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, formate was best described as a symmetrical bidentate or bridging species, rigid at 25 °C but exhibiting anisotropic motion at 220 °C. Surface carbonate formed readily from formate oxidation on Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 and was in equilibrium with free CO2. Zirconia is recognized as an effective support for copper nanoparticles in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. A detailed mechanistic investigation of CO2 hydrogenation on Cu/ZrO2 was conducted using NMR spectroscopy and isotopic labeling techniques [69]. Notably, NMR spectroscopy is more effective for detecting species adsorbed on zirconia than on metallic copper, as the latter can cause severe signal broadening. In the study, the Cu/ZrO2 catalyst was treated with a mixture of 13CO2 and H2 (1:3) for 12 h under pressures of 1 and 5 bar. After cooling to ambient temperature and evacuating the gas phase, the solid-state NMR was performed on the catalyst to detect adsorbed species. The 13C NMR signal at 168 ppm correlated with the 1H NMR signal at 8.4 ppm, indicating the presence of formate species. The broadening of the 1H signal suggested that formate was present in various chemical environments. After conducting the reaction at 5 bar, another correlation appeared at δ(13C) = 51 ppm and δ(1H) = 4.0 ppm, consistent with the formation of surface methoxy species. The absence of carbonates in both NMR and IR experiments indicated that these species were weakly adsorbed. The absence of carbonates in both in-situ IR and NMR experiments suggested that these intermediates were only weakly adsorbed. To investigate if formate is an intermediate in methanol synthesis, the researchers conducted isotopic labeling experiments. They first created 13C-labeled formate on Cu/ZrO2 and then treated the sample with D2 at 403 K and 5 bar for 12 h. Solid-state NMR and IR spectra showed formate and methoxy species, indicating that methoxy formed from deuteration of formate, suggesting its role as an intermediate. Further analysis with solution-state NMR confirmed the formation of deuterated methanol (13CD3OH) and indicated that formate exchanges hydrogen with deuterium before deuteration. These results supported that formate is indeed an intermediate in methanol synthesis. Similar results were obtained by Tsoukalou et al. [115] for In-Based ZrO2-Supported Catalysts. The 13C and 1H NMR spectra revealed unsupported In2O3 nanoparticles, m-ZrO2 (m- stands for monoclinic), and In2O3/am-ZrO2 (am- stands for amorphous) contained surface methoxy species. Additionally, m-ZrO2 and In2O3/am-ZrO2 showed formate species in various chemical environments. Unsupported In2O3 NPs primarily showed methoxy with minor formate signals. In contrast, In2O3/t-ZrO2 (t- stands for tetragonal) lacked detectable surface intermediates, confirming minimal methoxy and weak formate presence. Therefore, the stabilization of formate species was attributed to the interaction at the indium-zirconia interface or solid solution in m-ZrO2. The catalytic tests of various catalysts revealed a direct correlation between the quantities of formate and methoxy intermediates and both methanol selectivity and space–time yield. An exception to this trend was observed with In2O3/am-ZrO2, which, despite the detection of formate and methoxy species, exhibited low efficiency in methanol synthesis. The suboptimal performance of In2O3/am-ZrO2 can likely be attributed to an excessive stabilization of methoxy intermediates coupled with the rapid over-reduction of In2O3 over time. In contrast to the aforementioned research highlighting the importance of formate intermediates in the methanol synthesis process, Lam et al. [43], who investigated the synthesis of methanol on Cu-Zn/SiO2 catalyst using solid-state NMR spectroscopy, observed only the presence of methoxy species, with no detection of formate intermediates. The lack of formate intermediates was also reported for Cu-Ga/SiO2 catalyst [116]. High methanol selectivity and conversion for both catalysts were attributed to the absence of stable formate surface species, which could play a major role in improving methanol selectivity over CO. Moreover, it is demonstrated that highly stabilized formate species, as observed in the case of Cu/Al2O3, led to the preferential formation of CO. This is likely due to the generation of methyl formate at higher conversions, which can easily decompose into CO and MeOH [117]. Methanol synthesis via the reduction of CO2 with H2 is often accompanied by the undesired formation of CO through the reverse water–gas shift reaction. To gain a deeper mechanistic understanding of methanol formation from CO2 and H2 on highly selective Au/ZnO catalysts, Hartadi et al. [10] investigated the role of CO in the reaction process using isotope labeling experiments. Using 13C-labeled CO2 at 5 bar and 513 K, they found that (i) the Au/ZnO catalyst exhibited significantly higher activity for CO2 hydrogenation in CO2/H2 mixtures compared to CO hydrogenation in CO/H2 syngas. Additionally, in CO2/CO/H2 mixtures with up to equal amounts of CO and CO2 (15% CO2 and 15% CO), CO2 was the primary carbon source for methanol production. (ii) In CO2/CO/H2 mixtures, the proportion of methanol derived from CO increased linearly from 10% to around 20% as the CO content rose to 1%, beyond which the contribution of CO to methanol generation remained nearly constant. This phenomenon was likely due to the saturation of active CO adsorption sites under reaction conditions. (iii) The effectiveness of CO and CO2 hydrogenation was highly dependent on temperature. When CO2 and CO were present in equal amounts, CO2 remained the primary carbon source for methanol production at temperatures ranging from 513 K to 573 K. However, as the temperature increased, there was a growing shift towards CO hydrogenation. Thus, at even higher temperatures, CO was anticipated to eventually become the dominant contributor to methanol formation under similar conditions. Yang et al. [118] observed a support-dependent methanol selectivity for the In2O3/Li-ZrO2 catalyst. This result was attributed to the significant interaction between In2O3 and m-ZrO2 (m: monoclinic), confirmed through quasi-in-situ XPS experiments and supported by theoretical studies. In-situ Raman spectroscopy with different laser sources was used to analyze the structure of the In2O3/Li-ZrO2 catalyst at various depths. A 532 nm laser effectively detected phases in the bulk (depths > 50 nm), revealing monoclinic ZrO2 in In2O3/5Li-ZrO2, while a 269 cm−1 peak indicated tetragonal ZrO2 in In2O3/ZrO2 and In2O3/40Li-ZrO2. Ultraviolet Raman spectroscopy with a 325 nm laser detected the phase near the skin layer (about 10 nm deep), showing strong Eg vibrational modes of tetragonal ZrO2 in In2O3/ZrO2. Only monoclinic ZrO2 was detected in In2O3/5Li-ZrO2, indicating the monoclinic phase extends throughout the particle. In contrast, the bulk of In2O3/ZrO2 and In2O3/40Li-ZrO2 was mainly tetragonal. The peaks at 305 and 502 cm−1 corresponded to δ(InO6) and ν(InO6) units, while the 345 cm−1 peak is from InOIn structures on the ZrO2 surface. A higher proportion of InOIn structures in In2O3/5Li–ZrO2 suggested a stronger interaction between In2O3 and m-ZrO2, resulting in a higher methanol yield for this catalyst. Additionally, H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and D2-temperature-programmed surface reaction (D2-TPSR) experiments showed that H2 dissociation and HD formation occurred at lower temperatures over In2O3/5Li–ZrO2 compared to other catalysts. In2O3/5Li–ZrO2 also demonstrated a higher conversion of H2 to HD in the H2–D2 exchange reaction. These results suggest that the electron-rich In2O3 in In2O3/m-ZrO2 has higher activity in H–H bond dissociation, increasing the amount of dissociated H species and accelerating the rate of methanol formation. Raman and H2-TPR studies have confirmed distinct metal-support interactions for Cu/CeO2 and Cu/ZrO2 catalysts [119]. These differences lead to variations in reaction intermediates, resulting in different production selectivity for the two catalysts. The stronger interaction between Cu and the support enhances the dispersion and reducibility of CuO, increasing the number of Cu-CeO2 interfaces and the concentration of oxygen vacancies. These numerous interfaces facilitate the binding and activation of CO2, while the presence of oxygen vacancies significantly promotes charge accumulation and redistribution. This, in turn, enhances CO2 adsorption and stabilizes the key carbonate intermediates involved in methanol formation [120]. Sun et al. [121] focused on plate-like ZnO-supported Cu catalysts with varying microstructures for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, finding that Cu nanoparticles surrounded by relocated ZnOx were particularly effective for methanol production. The transformation of catalyst microstructures during the reduction process was monitored using in-situ Raman spectroscopy. All samples displayed similar peaks at around 434 cm−1 and 330 cm−1, attributed to the hexagonal wurtzite ZnO characteristic Raman active optical-phonon E2 and the multiphonon E2H-E2L modes, respectively. The E2 peak intensity increased as the Cu content rose from 1% to 10%, indicating enhanced crystallinity of ZnO. Additionally, the Raman peak at 550–600 cm−1, corresponding to the typical E1 (LO) mode associated with Zn-embedded atoms or Oxygen vacancy (Vo) sites, was observed [122]. The ratio of E1 (LO) mode intensity to E2 mode intensity (IE1/IE2) was employed to assess the migration of Zn prompted by strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) and to determine the presence of Vo. The E2 peak intensity of 1%Cu/ZnO significantly decreased during the reduction process as the temperature increased from room temperature to 300 °C, accompanied by a rise in the IE1/IE2 value. This confirms the SMSI-induced Zn migration, involving the formation of Zn-embedded atoms, or Vo, in 1%Cu/ZnO during the reduction process. H2-TPR measurements showed that the 1% Cu/ZnO sample had the highest reduction temperatures at 173 and 190 °C, attributed to the strong metal-support interactions between Cu and ZnO. In samples with a higher Cu ratio, lower reduction temperatures were observed due to larger aggregates, resulting in weaker interactions with the support. A reliable and consistent method for measuring the copper surface area involves monitoring the reaction of N2O with copper atoms. The most practical approach for in situ applications is reactive frontal chromatography (RFC), which is used in microreactors to evaluate the Cu surface area. After the MeOH synthesis, the gases are removed from the reactor, and the catalyst is exposed to a helium stream at near room temperature. A gas stream of 2.5% N2O in helium is then passed over the catalyst to estimate the surface area of metallic copper (Cu react) during methanol synthesis. The amount of N2 produced from the reaction between Cu and N2O is measured using a thermal conductivity detector at 60 °C. The total copper surface area of each catalyst (Cu total) is determined by the RFC technique after re-reducing the post-reaction catalysts with H2 at 523 K [123]. Research by Behrens et al. on Cu-Zn catalysts demonstrated that N2O-RFC not only measures the Cu surface area but also detects oxygen vacancies at the Cu-Zn interface [124]. Hinrichsen et al. [125] revealed a correlation between N2O-RFC surface area measurements and catalytic activity, indicating that N2O-RFC can effectively assess various Cu-based catalysts for methanol synthesis, despite some conceptual challenges. While this correlation is commonly observed, it is often mistakenly interpreted as a direct linear relationship between copper surface area and catalytic activity. This misconception has led to erroneous conclusions about the supposed structure insensitivity of methanol synthesis on Cu/ZnO-based catalysts [126]. Sehested et al. [127] reported that interpreting N2O-RFC results was more intricate than initially perceived. They analyzed various unsupported copper samples, discovering a linear correlation between N2O-RFC and hydrogen temperature-programmed desorption (H2-TPD) measurements (Fig. 6 ). However, when this linear correlation was compared with results from supported copper catalysts subjected to two distinct H2 treatment conditions (2)%H2/He at 120 °C for 3 h (M1) and pure H2 at 240 °C for 30 min (M2) (Fig. 6), substantial deviations from the pure copper references emerged. Hinrichsen et al. [125] previously noted that Cu/ZnO and Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts fell above this reference line. When a more intense H2 treatment (M2) was applied, the Cu/H ratio shifted, resulting in a higher N2O-RFC value and a lower H2-TPD value for the same catalyst. Particularly, Cu/CeO2 catalysts showed significant deviation from the reference line, likely due to the high reducibility of CeO2. Similarly, Cu/TiO2 also deviated considerably. Other catalysts, although retaining a linear relationship, fell below the reference line to various extents. Cu/Al2O3, Cu/ZrO2, and Cu/MgO displayed similar trends, whereas Cu/SiO2 exhibited a distinct and much lower relationship. These variations were attributed to the unique interactions and reducibility properties of the copper-support interfaces. 2.2 DFT and kinetic study 2.2.1 Methanol production pathway The industrial Cu–ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst is utilized for the production of CH3OH from syngas. This process occurs at temperatures within the range of 200–300 °C and pressures between 5 and 10 MPa. Despite the exothermic nature of the reaction, the conversion of CO2 to methanol is kinetically limited, achieving only 15–25%. Enhancing the catalytic performance of this catalyst has always been of interest, and one approach involves theoretically investigating the mechanism of the reaction. While many studies have proposed the formate pathway for methanol production from a mixture of CO2 and H2 in the presence of Cu-based catalysts [75,128], there has been notable interest in the rWGS reaction. This reaction involves the initial conversion of CO2 to CO, followed by hydrogenation to produce methanol [129]. A combined theoretical and experimental study was conducted to assess the likelihood of the two possible pathways in the synthesis of CH3OH over extended Cu(111) surfaces and Cu nanoparticles [130]. The results suggested that Cu nanoparticles exhibit higher activity in the conversion of CO2 to methanol compared to Cu(111). According to the DFT calculations, the synthesis of methanol on Cu surfaces follows a path involving an HCOO intermediate, with the rate-determining step being the hydrogenation of both HCOO and dioxomethylene (H2COO). The heightened efficacy of the nanoparticle arises from its non-rigidity and highly energetic Cu surface sites, which stabilize crucial intermediates like HCOO and H2COO. This stabilization lowers the activation energy of the rate-determining step. In addition to methanol synthesis, DFT calculations considered the experimentally observed rWGS reaction (CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O). The results aligned with experimental data, indicating that on Cu nanoparticles, the rate of the rWGS reaction is approximately two orders of magnitude faster than methanol synthesis at T = 573 K. Both experiments and calculations suggested that the CO generated by the rapid rWGS reaction accumulates as a product, without undergoing subsequent hydrogenation to form methanol. The pathway for methanol production via the rWGS reaction from CO hydrogenation is impeded by the initial hydrogenation of CO to form formyl (HCO), which is unstable and tends to dissociate into CO and H atoms on Cu. These findings proposed that incorporating dopants or promoters capable of stabilizing formyl species or facilitating the hydrogenation of formate and dioxomethylene can enhance methanol productivity on Cu-based catalysts. Hence, Santiago-Rodríguez and colleagues conducted thermodynamic investigations using DFT calculations on Cu(111) surfaces modified with titanium (Ti), gallium (Ga), and magnesium (Mg) [131].
