This catalyst proves highly efficient in liquid CO2 hydrogenation, delivering ethanol with an impressive initial turnover frequency of 481 h−1 and a high selectivity for ethanol (>99%) [92]. The dual-functional aspect of the Ir1–In2O3 catalyst, combining partially reduced In2O3 with a Lewis acid–base interaction between the single-atom Ir and neighboring oxygen vacancy (Vo), facilitates both the adsorption and activation of CO2 into CO*, and offers a favorable environment for C–C coupling between CH3O–Vo and Irδ+–CO. In the groundbreaking work by Ye et al. [293], a bifunctional single-atom catalyst on the optimized β-Mo2C was presented for highly selective hydrogenation of CO2 into ethanol. The researchers modified 1D Mo2C nanowires with dominant (101) crystal surfaces by depositing atomic components Rh and K. The resulting catalyst, K0.2Rh0.2/ β-Mo2C, exhibited a remarkable 72.1% ethanol selectivity at 150 °C, showcasing superior performance compared to unmodified β-Mo2C, which could only convert CO2 to methanol. The study highlighted that atomically dispersed Rh on β-Mo2C formed bifunctional active centers, showcasing synergistic effects that facilitated highly specific C–C coupling. The presence of Rh influenced the oxidation state of Mo, impacting CO2 activation. The introduction of an alkali metal (K) played a crucial role in enhancing CO2 adsorption and activation, leading to improved hydrogenation selectivity. Furthermore, the addition of K optimized the catalyst’s performance by regulating carrier properties and controlling H2 activation, resulting in reduced methanol production and enhanced ethanol selectivity. The paper concluded by underscoring the significance of synergistic bifunctional activities and controlled catalyst modification for efficiently converting CO2 to ethanol, presenting a novel strategy for the rational design of complex catalysts with substantial practical applications. Lou et al. [191] documented that CeO2-supported Pd dimers exhibited remarkable efficacy in converting CO2 to ethanol through thermocatalysis, achieving a superior space–time yield (STY) of 45.6 gethanol gPd −1 h−1. The pivotal function of Pd dimers in catalyzing the coupling of single carbon intermediates to form bicarbonate products was underscored in their study. Notably, these Pd dimers featured distinctive PdPd and PdO bonds arranged in a Pd2O4 configuration, demonstrating high homogeneity. This configuration enables the direct dissociation of CO2 to CO, instigating CC coupling while effectively inhibiting excessive C2+ coupling, thereby favoring the selective production of ethanol. Although Pd-based SACs typically lean towards generating CH4 and CH3OH, the unique characteristics of Pd dimers allow Pd single atoms to adsorb CH3* and CH3O* intermediates, facilitating the formation of ethanol and playing a crucial role in the evolution of ethanol. While achieving commendable results, this catalyst faced challenges related to low stability. Following that, in their subsequent investigations [294], they tackled this concern by introducing a silica layer to bolster the stability of the catalyst. The dual Pd sites’ stability was enhanced by creating a nanoreactor with a hydrophobic shell layer, leading to superior catalytic stability and ethanol selectivity. The catalyst demonstrated an impressive 98.7% ethanol selectivity, achieving a productivity of 11.6 g per gram of Pd per hour and maintaining excellent stability over a continuous 60-hour test. This breakthrough stems from the synergistic catalysis between dual Pd atoms, enabling the efficient cleavage of C–O bonds in *CHxOH species and promoting carbon–carbon coupling between *CHx and *CO species. The study underscores the significance of multifunctional synergistic catalysis and controlled catalyst modification in overcoming the limitations of single active site catalysts. Extensive research has been conducted on Rh-based catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 to higher alcohols, particularly ethanol. However, pure Rh exhibits selective restrictions on the formation of higher alcohols, with methane being the predominant product [295]. The introduction of dopants has proven to significantly enhance Rh’s catalytic activity [296]. For instance, Fe-Rh (111) effectively hindered CH4 formation, resulting in much higher ethanol selectivity. In the case of Mo-Rh (111) and Mn-Rh (111), they promoted CO insertion into CH3. Notably, Mo-Rh (111) with Mo at the surface layer exhibited the best activity and the highest total yield of ethanol. In an investigation conducted by Yang et al., a Rh1/CeTiOx single-atom catalyst, constructed by embedding monoatomic Rh onto a Ti-doped CeO2 support, demonstrated exceptional ethanol selectivity (approximately 99.1%), a record-breaking turnover frequency (493.1 h−1), and outstanding stability [297]. The remarkable catalytic performance observed in this study was attributed to the synergistic effects of Ti-doping and monoatomic Rh. This synergism plays a pivotal role by initially promoting the formation of oxygen vacancies, resulting in the creation of oxygen-vacancy-Rh Lewis-acid-base pairs. These pairs facilitate CO2 adsorption and activation, cleavage of CO bonds in CHxOH* and COOH* into CHx* and CO* species, followed by subsequent CC coupling and hydrogenation leading to ethanol formation. Additionally, the Ti-doping-induced crystal reconstruction generates a robust RhO bond, contributing significantly to the catalyst’s remarkable stability. Exploring Cu-based catalysts in CO2 hydrogenation for ethanol and higher alcohols has been a widespread focus. Achieving optimal yields of ethanol and higher alcohols with copper-based catalysts involves finding the right balance of promoters, such as alkali, transition metals, and their oxides, along with rare earth oxides. Strategic selection of operating variables is crucial to attain the desired activity and selectivity by suppressing undesired reactions [298]. Alkali-modified catalysts follow the HxCO-HxCO coupling chain growth mechanism, while FTS (Fe and Co) element-modified catalysts adopt the HxC-HxC coupling chain growth mechanism [299]. Both modifications enhance CC coupling ability on Cu-based catalysts, transforming CH3OH into C2+OH. For instance, Smith et al. noted that a 0.5% K2CO3 loading on the commercial copper-zinc oxide catalysts increased the formation of ethanol, n-propanol, and isobutyl alcohol [300]. Likewise, the introduction of a 5% potassium loading on the Co/Cu/ZnO catalyst resulted in a maximum in ethanol and higher-alcohols selectivity [301]. Furthermore, the incorporation of cesium (Cs) by other researchers resulted in similar effects. The majority of the studies indicated an optimal ratio for alkali loading, implying that elevated alkali loadings could potentially obstruct the active sites of the catalyst [302–305]. The zenith of copper catalytic activity for ethanol production occurred at the single CuI sites situated within a Zr12-cluster incorporated into a metal–organic framework (MOF) [106]. Assisted by an alkali cation, the CuI centers supported by the adjacent Zr12-cluster activated hydrogen and facilitated CC coupling, culminating in the synthesis of ethanol [106]. The Cs+-modified MOF catalyst exhibited impressive outcomes, achieving >99% selectivity and an unforeseen 96% conversion within a 10-hour duration. The catalytic activity stems from the synergistic behavior of bimetallic CuI 2 centers. These centers not only facilitate H2 activation but also enable the direct formation of C–C bond between CH3OH and HCO intermediates, aided by alkali-metal promoter elements. The presence of alkali-metals creates a high electron density around Cu sites, enhancing the catalyst activity by stabilizing HCO species (Fig. 20 ). 4.2.2 Nanoparticle catalysts Heterogeneous catalysts, comprised of two key components, support, and active site are generally synthesized using two common methods: precipitation and impregnation. The support in these catalysts plays a crucial role by providing a stable framework or substrate for the active sites. The support material not only imparts mechanical strength but also influences the surface area, porosity, and overall stability of the catalyst. Additionally, the choice of support can impact the dispersion of active sites and their accessibility to reactants, thereby influencing the catalytic activity and selectivity of the overall reaction. Bai et al. [101] delved deeper into the performance of Pd2Cu nanoparticles over various mesopore supports (P25, Al2O3, CeO2, and SiO2) for CO2 hydrogenation at 200 °C. The yields of C2H5OH for Pd2Cu NPs/P25, Pd2Cu NPs/Al2O3, Pd2Cu NPs/CeO2, and Pd2Cu NPs/SiO2 were recorded at 41.5, 19.7, 16.2, and 14.8 mmol g−1 h−1, respectively. Notably, Pd2Cu NPs/CeO2 exhibited the highest CH3OH yield, attributed to the potential enhancement of Cu activity in CO2 to CH3OH conversion facilitated by CeO2. Among the four catalysts, Pd2Cu NPs/P25 demonstrated superior catalytic performance, showcasing the highest TOFPd and selectivity of C2H5OH. This excellence is attributed to the presence of oxygen vacancies on P25, which facilitate the process of CO2 hydrogenation. A range of cobalt catalysts promoted by sodium, denoted as Na–Co-Support (Support = Al2O3, TiO2, ZnO, Active Carbon (AC), SiO2, and Si3N4), with equivalent amounts of Na and Co, were also utilized to investigate the influence of the support material on the direct hydrogenation of CO2 [306]. The catalysts supported by SiO2 and Si3N4 demonstrated effective ethanol generation, achieving an 18% CO2 conversion rate and a 62% selectivity in the alcohol distribution at 250 °C. In contrast, other supported catalysts predominantly produced methane (Fig. 21 ). Yang et al. [110] discovered that among various supports examined in CO2 hydrogenation, the TiO2 nanorod (NR) support exhibited superior performance for the 1 wt% RhFeLi active site, particularly excelling in the synthesis of ethanol from CO2 hydrogenation. They proposed two key advantages of the TiO2 NR support in producing ethanol: (i) the strong interaction between the active sites and TiO2 NR support led to the highly dispersed state of Rh-based nanoparticles, resulting in heightened activity; (ii) the abundance of hydroxyl groups on TiO2 NRs facilitated the protonation of methanol, easily dissociating it into *CHx, thereby promoting the preferential formation of ethanol through CO insertion. The conclusion drawn was that finding a universally suitable support for all catalysts is not feasible; the optimal support selection relies on the intricate interplay and synergistic effects between the support material and the catalyst. The potential impact of the support on the dispersion and stability of the catalysts emerges as a crucial factor in determining the most suitable support. Similarly, the introduction of metal onto the supports has an impact on both the conversion of reactants and the desired product selectivity. Therefore, it is crucial to optimize the metal loading to guarantee the formation of the targeted product. This emphasizes the need for careful consideration and adjustment of the metal content to achieve the desired outcomes in the production of ethanol through CO2 hydrogenation. The metals that have been mostly used for this process are Co [307,308], Cu [309], Fe [310], Pd [294], Rh [311–313], Au [314], and Pt [100] (Table 3 ). The comparative analysis of the batch reactor and continuous flow bed reactor components in Table 3 indicates a greater selectivity for the batch reactor. Uniform residence time and consistent reaction conditions, such as temperature and catalyst exposure, are critical factors in enhancing ethanol selectivity in a batch reactor. In a CSTR, the continuous stirring ensures that all reactants are evenly mixed, leading to a uniform temperature throughout the reactor and consistent contact with the catalyst. This uniformity prevents the development of hot spots or temperature gradients that could favor side reactions. Additionally, the more consistent residence time distribution in a CSTR allows for precise control over the reaction time, minimizing the chances of over-reaction or the formation of by-products. In contrast, a fixed-bed reactor often experiences variations in residence time and uneven catalyst exposure, leading to less controlled reaction conditions and reduced selectivity for ethanol. A noticeable shift towards methanol and CO as the major products was observed in the continuous flow bed reactor. This implies that these reactors may lack the sufficient capability to dissociate CHxOH* into CHx*and subsequently couple with CO*, likely due to the extremely short residence time in the reactor. However, for practical applications, the continuous-flow fixed-bed reactor is particularly advantageous due to its solvent-free operation and lower manufacturing costs. Rh, known for its proficiency in CC bond formation, is a commonly chosen precious metal for producing higher alcohols. Nevertheless, the incorporation of transition metals or alkali-metal promoters becomes essential to elevate the efficiency of these catalysts. Kusama et al. [89] investigated the impact of plenty of different additives on the performance of a Rh/SiO2 catalyst in CO2 hydrogenation. In a fixed-bed reactor with a Rh:M (M: metal additive) atomic ratio of 1:1, operating at T = 240 °C and P = 50 bar, it was discovered that among 30 additives tested, only Ag, Sr, Fe, and Li induced ethanol formation, with selectivities of 1.8%, 2.5%, 3.2%, and 15.5%, respectively. Table 3 demonstrates that palladium, particularly in single-atom or dimer configurations, exhibits high selectivity in the hydrogenation of CO2 to ethanol. Co in various forms like Co0, CoO, and cobalt carbide (Co2C) can trigger the activation of carbon dioxide (CO2) and generate C1 intermediates such as CHx*, CO*, and HCOO*. These intermediates play a crucial role in the synthesis of C2+ products like ethanol. Some strategies can potentially enhance the coupling of CHx*–CO*/HCOO* and, in turn, boost the synthesis of ethanol through CO2 hydrogenation [315]. These strategies include i) designing Co0-CoO hetero-site catalysts by tailoring the reduction process [211], ii) incorporating alkali metal to create hetero-site Co-based catalysts [197,316], iii) developing hetero-site Co catalysts via Co-support/promoter interaction [103]. Cu, widely recognized as a catalyst in commercial methanol synthesis, has garnered interest for its potential in the hydrogenation of CO2 to ethanol. Efforts to shift the catalytic activity of Cu from methanol to ethanol have focused on introducing an alkali metal [16], along with Fe [95], due to its specific heightened activity in the rWGS reaction. Fe species boost CO cleavage, CC coupling, and hydrogenation reactions, whereas Cu species facilitate the non-cleavage of CO. Alkali-metal promoters contribute to diminishing alkane production, reducing methanol production, and ensuring an equilibrium between the centers involved in both the cleavage (iron sites) and non-cleavage (copper sites) of CO [317]. Zhang et al. [192] investigated the performance of a Co2C||CZA catalyst in a tandem system for CO2 hydrogenation to produce higher alcohols, specifically in a dual-bed configuration. The study demonstrated that the highest selectivity for higher alcohols was achieved when the feed gas first contacted the Co2C catalyst in the dual-bed setup. Alternative configurations, such as different dual-bed arrangements, physical mixing of the powders, or using an impregnated Co/CZA catalyst, were largely ineffective in producing higher alcohols. The researchers proposed that this specific configuration could finely tune the reaction mechanism, thereby optimizing the selectivity for the target products. Using in-situ DRIFTS technique, the authors suggested the following mechanism for the formation of higher alcohols including ethanol: CO2 initially undergoes hydrogenation on the Co2C catalyst, producing olefins. These olefins then migrate to the CZA sites, where they convert into R-CH2 intermediates. These intermediates subsequently interact with CHO* groups at the Cu/ZnAl2O4 interface, leading to the formation of higher alcohols. The strategic incorporation of multiple active sites within this catalyst design efficiently generates the necessary R-CH2* and CHO* intermediates, promoting CC coupling and resulting in a high space–time yield of higher alcohols (STYHA) of 2.2 mmol g(cat) −1 h−1. The similar STYHA was reported for multifunctional catalyst composed of CZA and K-CuMgZnFe (K-CMZF) oxides [318]. However, different role for CZA was discovered in HAs synthesis using in-situ DRIFTS. In this system, the catalytic performance in CO2 hydrogenation to HAs is primarily influenced by two factors: the synergetic effect and the proximity effect of two components of the catalyst. Analysis of DRIFTS and temperature-programmed surface reaction (TPSR) data revealed that the CZA component promotes CO formation, while the K-CMZF component facilitates the conversion of COx to HA via a CO insertion mechanism. The strong synergy between these components, particularly when combined in a balanced mass ratio (such as 1:1), ensures efficient and continuous transformation of CO2 into CO* and subsequently into HA, as the reaction rates are well-matched. The catalytic performance of the CuZnAl||K-CMZF catalyst revealed that the proximity of the two constituent components is of great importance. Closer contact between the two components, such as through powder mixing rather than a dual-bed configuration, resulted in the highest CO2 conversion, HA selectivity, and space–time yield (STY). However, overly proximity, as in mortar mixing, reduced catalytic activity due to potential potassium poisoning of CZA from K-CMZF, emphasizing the need for an optimal distance between the catalyst components. 5 Conclusions and recommendations In summary, the development of effective catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation is closely tied to a profound comprehension of the interplay between the structure of the catalyst and surface species, as well as a thorough understanding of the underlying mechanistic principles that govern the reaction. The catalytic activity of a catalyst is intricately influenced by various factors, including the nature of the active site, the interaction between active sites and support, the presence of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface, and the role of additives. Modulating these factors allows for the adjustment of the balance between surface species, leading to the production of diverse products. While IR technique is widely recognized for identifying intermediates and offering valuable information about surface species, it falls short in providing details about the nature and oxidation states of active sites. This limitation becomes particularly apparent in the case of multifunctional catalysts, where each functional group is responsible for generating distinct intermediates. In recent years, advanced high-pressure operando techniques such as XAS, XPS, and XRD analysis have been employed in catalytic reactions. These techniques contribute to determining the nature and electronic properties of active sites on catalysts, as well as shedding light on the binding of intermediates to active sites. In addition, DFT calculations and kinetic studies have consistently captivated interest due to their role in identifying predominant intermediates and offering insights into potential reaction pathways. The combination of these findings provides a rational and enhanced understanding of the design of a selective and efficient catalyst. While Cu-based catalysts, particularly Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, remain the primary choice for industrial methanol production due to their favorable conversion-to-selectivity ratio, there is an ongoing imperative to improve the performance of the applied catalyst in this area. The key challenge lies in elevating metal efficiency to achieve a higher methanol formation rate, with single atom catalysts emerging as a potential avenue for improvement. Another issue that catalysts likely experience is the rapid deactivation due to the inevitable presence of H2O as a byproduct, sulfur compounds in feedstock, and the accumulation of carbonaceous deposits on the catalyst surface. Thus, the development of robust catalysts is essential to address these challenges. Notably, In2O3 exhibits improved water resilience, and ZnO/ZrO2 demonstrates sulfur resistance; however, they suffer from low CO2 conversion. Moreover, previous studies have documented those precious metals like Pd and Pt are capable of synthesizing methanol at lower temperatures, but their high metal loading increases overall costs. Therefore, considerations of energy efficiency and economic feasibility are paramount before practical application. Exploring noble metal-based single atom catalysts with high activation and selectivity holds promise for transitioning from laboratory-scale success to industrial-scale implementation. However, each group of catalysts presents specific challenges, underscoring the need for a deeper comprehension of reaction mechanisms for further advancement in catalyst design. For example, formate has been widely introduced as a key intermediate in the methanol process, but its role as a reaction intermediate or spectator species remains unclear. Recent research on methanol synthesis over Pd-ZnO, employing time-resolved isotope labeling experiments coupled with mass and FTIR spectroscopies, revealed the involvement of formate species in the catalytic cycle. This underscores the importance of the catalyst's structure and electronic configuration in increasing and stabilizing formate formation, ultimately enhancing the methanol yield. In contrast to the relatively straightforward process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the synthesis of ethanol presents a greater challenge. This complexity arises from the necessity of facilitating CC bond formation within surface moieties before desorption as a C1 product or further hydrogenation to other products. Despite nearly four decades having passed since the initial report on CO2 hydrogenation to higher alcohols, the inherently low activity and selectivity exhibited by most heterogeneous catalysts have prevented significant progress toward industrialization. Comparing the outcomes of studies conducted in the batch reactor and continuous flow bed reactor demonstrates a greater selectivity in the batch reactor. Notably, the continuous flow bed reactor exhibits a marked shift towards methanol and CO as the predominant products. The most favorable outcome is observed with the Zr12-bpdc-CuCs MOF catalyst in the batch reactor. MOFs present a versatile platform that enables the adjustment of distances and positions among various active sites, proving highly advantageous for ethanol synthesis. However, the synthesis of MOFs can pose challenges as it tends to be both laborious and expensive. Although a few research studies have utilized operando X-ray techniques for CO2 conversion to methanol, additional investigations are needed to unveil the catalyst structure changes and coordination environment of active sites during the reaction. There is a lack of mechanism studies for CO2 conversion to ethanol using these techniques, which points to a gap in our understanding of this process. Recent research has spotlighted dual-Pd atom catalysts, demonstrating a high selectivity of more than 90%. The prospect of single-atom catalysts in a dimer position emerges as a potential breakthrough for ethanol synthesis in the future. Conducting more operando analysis mechanism studies is crucial to unravel the specific roles of each atom in the dimer position, clarifying whether they play similar roles and possess identical electronic configurations. Given that C–C coupling is anticipated between oxygenate intermediates (CHxO) and alkyl, the incorporation of hetero dual-atom compositions can represent a promising and evolving strategy in catalyst design for future studies. Exploring non-noble metals as alternatives to precious metals like Pd is also a prudent choice for further investigation. Furthermore, a majority of the highly effective Co-based and Cu-based catalysts employ alkali metals as promoters. Undoubtedly, alkali metals play a pivotal role in the CO2 hydrogenation to ethanol. Additional studies focusing on the mechanism are essential to generate novel insights that unravel the distinct roles of alkali metals in this process. Finally, incorporating other techniques can provide supplementary insights alongside those obtained from X-ray analysis. For example, while X-ray results can reveal chemical details across a broad spectrum of sizes, from tens of nanometers up to the millimeter range, TEM technique is required to examine structures at the atomic level, offering insights at sub-nanometer resolution. Edman Tsang, ACS Catal. 11 (2021) 8978–8984. Rasoul Salami earned his MSc from Sharif University of Technology and his PhD in Chemistry from Tarbiat Modares University. In 2023, he joined Professor Zheng’s research group in the Department of Chemical Engineering at Western University. His research focuses on the design and development of catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation into valuable products. Yimin Zeng is a leading research scientist at Natural Resources Canada (NRCan) CanmetMATERIALS, and also an adjunct professor at the University of Waterloo, Western University, and the University of Albert. His current research focuses on addressing materials technology and corrosion science challenges for the development and deployment of CO2 capture, utilization, and storage, advanced bioenergy production and application, next generation nuclear and thermal power systems, hydrogen energy, novel battery materials, decarbonisation technologies in oil/gas industry etc. Xue Han is currently a Research Scientist at CanmetMATERIALS, Natural Resources Canada. She received her PhD degree from University of New Brunswick in 2014. Her research focuses on the materials development in the sustainable utilization of CO2 and thermochemical production of bioenergy. Sohrab Rohani is currently a full Professor in the Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering at the University of Western Ontario, where he also served as the past Chair. His research focuses on pharmaceutical design and the application of artificial intelligence in pharmaceutical crystallization. He received the Engineering Medal in Research and Development from the Professional Engineers, Ontario, in 2008 and the Western Faculty of Engineering Award for Excellence in Research in 2009. He has authored over 400 refereed journal publications. Ying Zheng is a full professor and Canada Research Chair in the Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering at the University of Western Ontario, Canada. With a focus on catalysis and clean energy, she specializes in developing novel catalytic materials and processes for applications in CO2 utilization, N2 fixation, H2 production and clean/biofuel upgrading. Group website: https://www.eng.uwo.ca/chemical/zheng-research/index.html.

coredata.dc:description: The pursuit of alternative fuel generation technologies has gained momentum due to the diminishing reserves of fossil fuels and global warming from increased CO2 emission. Among the proposed methods, the hydrogenation of CO2 to produce marketable carbon-based products like methanol and ethanol is a practical approach that offers great potential to reduce CO2 emissions. Although significant volumes of methanol are currently produced from CO2, developing highly efficient and stable catalysts is crucial for further enhancing conversion and selectivity, thereby reducing process costs. An in-depth examination of the differences and similarities in the reaction pathways for methanol and ethanol production highlights the key factors that drive C–C coupling. Identifying these factors guides us toward developing more effective catalysts for ethanol synthesis. In this paper, we explore how different catalysts, through the production of various intermediates, can initiate the synthesis of methanol or ethanol. The catalytic mechanisms proposed by spectroscopic techniques and theoretical calculations, including operando X-ray methods, FTIR analysis, and DFT calculations, are summarized and presented. The following discussion explores the structural properties and composition of catalysts that influence C–C coupling and optimize the conversion rate of CO2 into ethanol. Lastly, the review examines recent catalysts employed for selective methanol and ethanol production, focusing on single-atom catalysts.

coredata.dc:title: Exploring catalyst developments in heterogeneous CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and ethanol: A journey through reaction pathways
